p: Above all, cultivation of medicinal halophytes that strengthen the immune system in haloculture systems and its consumption with medical considerations, can reduce some of the negative effects of COVID-19. For example, Khaerunnisa et al. (2020) surveyed some compounds in medicinal plants and recommended kaempferol, quercetin, luteolin-7-glucoside, apigenin-7-glucoside, naringenin, oleuropein, demethoxycurcumin, curcumin, catechin, and epigallocatechin as potential inhibitors of COVID-19. These compounds are found in various plant species including spinach ( Spinacia oleracea), dill ( Anethum graveolens), olive ( Olea europaea), turmeric ( Curcuma longa), tea plant ( Camellia sinensis) and ginger ( Zingiber officinale). Some plants such as licorice (Glycyrrhiza glabra), mangrove ( Avicennia marina), pomegranate ( Punica granatum), pistachio ( Pistacia vera) and ginger ( Zingiber officinale), have varied levels of salinity tolerance. Most of these plants, with high salinity tolerance can grow in saline agrecosystems. Licorice is a plant that easily grows and reproduces as a native species in saline environments. Pomegranates and especially pistachios, are trees that are cultivated in saline soils using saline water in many areas, and mangrove is a tree that grows naturally in very salty water (more than 40 dS m −1) off the coast ( Pirasteh-Anosheh, 2020; Pirasteh-Anosheh et al., 2016).
